sub_title: Textile & Apparel Designer, Instructor, Consultant at Eloïse Ptito
summary:
Eloïse Ptito-Echeverria is a textile-apparel designer and hand-embroidery instructor currently based in Amsterdam, NL. Driven by intelligent print and ethical design, she possesses a particular penchant for textiles, embroidery, and bold colour. 

After completing her Fine Arts degree in 2011, she reconnected with her roots and lived in Santiago, Chile for a year where she apprenticed in Rococo hand-embroidery and studied Precolumbian-Andina textiles at l’Universidad Catolica de Diseño. Upon graduating from Ryerson University’s School of Fashion (SOF), her designs went on to be shown at Toronto Women’s Fashion Week and at The Canadian Fashion History Museum’s exhibit, "Then Now Next”; showcasing Canada’s most influential designers from both past and present. Later that year, she was awarded Brettons’ Designer of the Year (2017). Her work has additionally been showcased within Selvedge Magazine (UK), The Toronto Star, The Kit, Blanc Magazine, Not Just a Label, and at the Condé Nast International Luxury Conference in Lisbon, Portugal.

www.eloiseptito.com
@eloiseptito

treasury_media.title: Arpillera and Resistance - Eloïse Ptito-Echeverria
treasury_media.description:
Recent write-up about my Arpillera Workshop in partnership with Selvedge Magazine (UK): 
"The word arpillera originally refers to the coarse woven fabric that is used for sacking, often called jute or burlap in the UK and US. As artworks, Arpillera are created through appliqué or embroidery on a background of this sack cloth, hand stitched..."

treasury_media.title: Not just for grannies, quilting gets a revival as an art form that tells a story
treasury_media.description: "As a newcomer to Amsterdam during the pandemic, Ptito-Echeverria began making arpillera. “Cooped up inside day after day, I naturally began to turn back to these textiles of my childhood, crafting better, imagined worlds through cloth. "

education.degree_name: Fashion Design, Bachelor of Fine Arts (B.F.A.)

awards.title: Brettons' Designer of the Year Award
awards.description: Awarded Brettons' Designer of the Year Award for excellence in Fourth Year Fashion Design & Thesis Collection.

awards.title: Featured in Mode Canada & Fashion History Museum Exhibit "THEN NOW NEXT"
awards.description: Designs from my final thesis collection "The Many Muses", were featured in Mode Canada’s Yorkville Village exhibit, “Then Now Next”. Curated by the Fashion History Museum, the exhibit celebrates various Canadian designers from the past 150 years up until today and tomorrow.  Personal designs were featured in the “NEXT: Form, Flow, Function Perfected as Art” section which focused on Canada's promising and emerging designers.

awards.title: Final Collection Shown at Toronto Fashion Week (TWFW)
awards.description: Recently chosen by TWFW to have pieces from final thesis collection shown at the opening of Toronto Fashion Week.

awards.title: Recipient of Art Installation Funding for "Taking Roots: Our Canada" Exhibit
awards.description: Art Installation proposal approved and funded by the Hispanic Canadian Heritage Council (HCHC), Centre for Spanish-Speaking Peoples (CSSP), and Art Gallery of Ontario (AGO). Received $3500.00 grant to create a wearable art garment installation. Art Dress Installation to be featured in exhibit, "Taking Roots: Our Canada", alongside  five other emerging artists of Latinx-descent under 29 years of age.  Exhibit explores the complexities of the Latinx identity and diaspora within Canada.
awards.issuer: Hispanic Canadian Heritage Council (HCHC), Centre for Spanish-Speaking Peoples CSSP, AGO

awards.title: Finalist in Ryerson’s Mass Exodus 2017 Curated Show
awards.description: Finalist in Ryerson’s Mass Exodus 2017 Curated Show , selected by judges Byron and Dexter Peart of WANT Les Essentiels

awards.title: Ryerson International Work Experience Fund (RIWEF) Recipient
awards.description: Received $1000.00 funding for Fashion Internship abroad in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

awards.title: Ryerson Summer Company Grant Recipient
awards.description: Received $3000.00 funding to launch personal clothing label, "Fauve".

profile_positions.description: Freelance Textile & Apparel Designer, Consultant, Instructor, and Curation. 2020- Presently
profile_positions.title: Freelance Textile Designer

profile_positions.description:
Designer, Curator, Researcher, and Merchandising Coordinator at Byron & Dexter Peart's new purpose-led design platform "Goodee". 

- Recruited by Byron & Dexter Peart as very first employee and was entrusted to help carve out the venture's unique voice and vision as a brand since its very beginnings.

- Chose and sourced various company textiles, while involved in the design, coordination and conceptualization of Goodee’s first line of limited-edition Tote Bags, Market Bags and Pillows made in collaboration with the United Nation’s Ethical Fashion Initiative (EFI). In partnership with EFI and aligning with the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDG), the exclusive series were brought to life using textiles handwoven by artisans in Burkina Faso and produced by social cooperatives in both Kenya and Italy.

- Assisted in the design and conceptualization of the most recent Goodee Hoodies in collaboration with the sustainable fashion company KOTN.

- Most recently involved with the research and merchandise coordination of Goodee's collaborative pop-up at the Whitney Museum Shop in New York City, inspired by their newest exhibit, “Making Knowing: Craft in Art, 1950 – 2019”. Succeeded in creating Goodee's pitch presentation, as well as finding artisans far and wide with a unique story and positive social impact to be featured at the Whitney Museum Shop.
